article.description: Allan Houston got the better of Glen Rice on the most important play of the game, spoiling Rice's first game at Madison Square Garden since being traded as New York defeated Houston 89-86 on Monday night.
article.headline: Rice has big game, but Knicks have last laugh

images.name: Houston_Allan 120301 inline
images.caption: Allan Houston may not have been effective against Glen Rice on defense, but he got the best of Rice on a key drive late in the fourth quarter.

article.linkText: Rice cooked in final moments as Knicks edge Rockets
article.story:
NEW YORK (AP) -- On a night when the Glen Rice trade looked like a steal for the Houston Rockets, the New York Knicks could at least take solace in a victory. Allan Houston got the better of Rice on the most important play of the game, spoiling Rice's return to Madison Square Garden for the first time since being traded as the Knicks beat the Rockets 89-86 Monday night. Rice scored a season-high 20 points and was at his best when matched against Houston, repeatedly driving around and scoring over his former teammate. But when Houston got the ball isolated against Rice with 18 seconds left, he dribbled to his left and launched a quick jumper from the baseline to give New York an 87-85 lead. "He hit a tough shot, but Allan has done that over and over and over. There wasn't really much I could do," Rice said. From there, Houston and Latrell Sprewell each made one of two free throws and the Knicks survived an off-balance 3-point attempt by Cuttino Mobley just before the final buzzer to win for the fourth time in five games. Sprewell scored 23, Houston 22 and Charlie Ward had eight points and six assists while playing the final 16 minutes and leading the Knicks back from a 17-point deficit. Ward took over because Knicks coach Jeff Van Gundy lost confidence in Howard Eisley, who was acquired along with Shandon Anderson in the Rice trade. Anderson shot 0-for-4 from the field and 1-for-4 from the line in the first half and did not play in the second half, while Eisley played seven scoreless and assist-free minutes and also sat out the second half. Rice chuckled when asked whether the Knicks got enough in return, then chose his words carefully. "The guys they got, I'm not going to say anything to discredit those guys, but they definitely don't have the jump shot that I have," said Rice, who spent just one season with the Knicks. He shot 5-for-5 and scored 11 points in the first quarter and surpassed his previous season-high of 15. Kenny Thomas also scored 20 for Houston. Mobley returned after missing three games due to a sprained ankle but scored only eight points. "I did not like the shot selection at the end of the game," coach Rudy Tomjanovich said. "They should have just gotten a good shot." Despite Rice's start, the Knicks opened a 28-18 lead late in the first. In the second quarter, however, New York made only 4 of 19 shots as Houston came back to take a 42-38 lead at intermission. A pair of jumpers by Mobley sandwiched around an airball by Sprewell made it 64-47 midway through the third, and Van Gundy turned to Ward in an effort to find a spark. "Charlie definitely gave us a lift," Sprewell said. "He's been sitting for a while, but to keep himself ready to play -- you have to commend him for that." Ward, who hadn't played in eight of the previous nine games, hit his first two shots and had five assists to help cut the deficit to 72-71 with eight minutes left. Rice hit his next three shots to get Houston's lead up to 83-77, and the Knicks weren't able to tie it until Houston hit a 22-foot jumper with 54 seconds left to make it 85-85. Game notes
Sprewell and Thomas had a brief but nasty confrontation in the third quarter after Thomas poked Sprewell in the ribs as he released a shot and Sprewell retaliated by chasing down Thomas and hitting him in the back with his forearm. "I'm glad he didn't take one more step toward me," Sprewell said. Thomas refused comment. ... Venezuelan guard Oscar Torres had an impressive dunk over Anderson in the second quarter. New York's Othella Harrington also had a crowd-pleasing stuff early in the fourth quarter. ... The Rockets, who were 25-5 against teams from the Eastern Conference last season, are now 2-1 against the East.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
